p-value: The probability of obtaining test results at least as extreme as the observed results, assuming the null hypothesis is true. A smaller p-value indicates stronger evidence against the null hypothesis.
Null Hypothesis: The default assumption that there is no significant difference or relationship between variables. Statistical tests aim to either reject or fail to reject this hypothesis.
Effect Size: A quantitative measure of the magnitude of a phenomenon. Common measures include Cohen's d, Pearson's r, and odds ratios.
Statistical Power: The probability that a test will correctly reject a false null hypothesis. Higher power means a lower chance of Type II errors.
Type I Error: False positive - rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true.
Type II Error: False negative - failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is actually false.
Confidence Interval: A range of values that likely contains the true population parameter. The confidence level (e.g., 95%) indicates the probability that the interval contains the parameter.
Normal Distribution: A continuous probability distribution characterized by a symmetric bell-shaped curve. Many statistical tests assume data follows this distribution.
Non-parametric Tests: Statistical tests that don't assume a specific distribution of the data. Examples include Mann-Whitney U test and Kruskal-Wallis test.
Repeated Measures: A study design where the same subjects are measured multiple times under different conditions.
Independent Groups: A study design where different subjects are assigned to different groups or conditions.
Hierarchical Data: Data with a nested structure, such as students within classes within schools.
Time Series: A sequence of data points collected over time, typically at regular intervals.
